intro.para: Here we learn how to distinguish various types of matrices by their shape, respectively by properties of their entries. Some of these concepts will only be needed later. Therefore, this section can be skipped on a first reading and used as a reference when needed.

def.caption: Square Matrix

info.para: Some examples of square shaped and non-square shaped matrices.

def.para:
A matrix is square shaped if the number of its rows equals the number of its columns; i.e. if it is of size (n,n) for some n\geq 1.
squarematrix

def.caption: Row Matrix

info.caption: On row matrices
info.para: A row matrix is one which has exactly one row, i.e. is of size (1,n). Thus the matrices below are row matrices.

def.para:
A matrix of size (1,n) is called a row matrix.
rowmatrix

def.caption: Column Matrix

info.caption: On column matrices
info.para: A column matrix is one which has exactly one column, i.e. is of size (m,1). Thus the matrices below are column matrices.

def.para:
A matrix of size (m,1) is called a column matrix.
columnmatrix
Column Matrix
A matrix of size (m,1) is called a column matrix.
matrixof one column
Column Matrix
A matrix of size (m,1) is called a column matrix.

comment.caption: on Vectors vs. Row / Column Matrices

info.para: Details on the distinction between vectors / row matrices / column matrices.

comment.para: It can be advantageous to write a vector (x_1,\dots ,x_n) in \RNr[n] alternately as a row matrix of size (1,n) or a column matrix of size (n,1).

def.caption: Identity Matrix

info.para: A display of the identity matrices \IdMtrx[1], \IdMtrx[2], \IdMtrx[3], \IdMtrx[4].

def.para:
The (n,n)-identity matrix is the square matrix with n rows and n columns whose diagonal entries are all equal to 1, and all other entries are equal to 0. We write \IdMtrx[n] for this matrix.

def.caption: Upper Triangular Matrix

info.para: A display of some upper triangular matrices.

def.para:
An upper triangular matrix is square shaped and only entries on or above the diagonal are allowed to be different from 0.
